p: The mean age of patients in the present study was 57 ± 15 years. The mean or median ages were different in published studies, from 46 to 65 years ( 31, 32). The male gender was dominant in our study, resembling other studies of COVID-19 ( 5, 32). Although gender difference is evident in many studies of COVID-19, it does not affect outcomes. However, in one study, critically ill males had higher mortality ( 33). This difference was first explained by the increase in expression of ACE2 (the receptor for entrance of SARS-CoV2 to the cell) in Asian men ( 34). Later, the issue was attributed to the higher rate of cigarette smoking in Asian men than Asian women. However, both hypotheses should be confirmed in future studies. At present, neither gender nor smoking is certainly correlated with severity of COVID-19 ( 35).
